origination.corpname: St. Mary Student Parish (Ann Arbor, Mich.)

did.unittitle: St. Mary Student Parish (Ann Arbor, Mich.) Records 1915-2000
did.abstract: Catholic chapel (later parish) ministering largely to University of Michigan students. Council minutes, correspondence, topical files, chapel bulletins, and financial records; also files relating to the Gabriel Richard Foundation, and the Newman Club; and photographs.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The records were deposited by St. Mary Student Parish (donor no. 5601) in 1981. Periodic additions have been made.

accessrestrict.p: The record group is open to research.

userestrict.p: Copyright is retained by the parish.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, St. Mary Student Parish (Ann Arbor, Mich.) Records, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: St. Mary Student Chapel (now Parish) of the Immaculate Conception (Ann Arbor) traces its origin to 1914 when the auxiliary bishop of Detroit appointed Father Michael Patrick Bourke to begin organizing a separate congregation for Catholic students attending the University of Michigan. Catholic students on campus at that time numbered approximately 600, and it was felt time to provide a facility for their "religious welfare." The first site of the chapel was the Morris property on the southwest corner of Jefferson and State streets which had been secured on March 26, 1915. The Morris home was soon inadequate to meet the needs of the growing Catholic student population, and thus a fund-raising program for the construction of a new building was initiated. Owing to a decision of the University's Board of Regents in 1922 under their power of "eminent domain" to condemn the proposed site of the chapel for state use, Father Bourke, who had been appointed chaplain of the "University Chapel" on April 12, 1919, was forced to secure a second site on which to build. With the moneys raised, he subsequently purchased a parcel of land on the northeast corner of William and Thompson streets for the sum of 29 thousand dollars. Construction of the chapel began in July 1923, and was completed on April 7, 1924 with the laying of the cornerstone. The Student Chapel was officially dedicated on February 29, 1925.

A Newman Club was organized at the Chapel in 1930. Taking its name from the famous English Catholic theologian of the 19th century, the first Newman Club had originated at the University of Pennsylvania in 1893 and soon spread westward. The purpose of the Club at the University of Michigan was "to sponsor the educational and social phases of the Chapel program." The club at the University was reorganized in the mid-1930s, and the first meeting of the modern Newman Club was held on January 23, 1938. On March 5, 1939, the Club began the publication of its bulletin, the Chapel Chronicle.

The subsequent growth of the Newman Club made necessary the building of a facility which could both serve as a student center and as the home of the Newman activities. The Father Gabriel Richard Center was the inspiration of Father Frank J. McPhillip, who coordinated a highly successful nation-wide fundraising campaign among Catholic alumni of the University. The building was formally dedicated November 22, 1953.

scopecontent.p: The records of St. Mary Student Parish are divided into six series: (1) St. Mary Chapel administrative files; (2) Gabriel Richard Center records; (3) Newman Club records; (4) Miscellaneous records; (5) Newsletters; and (6) Photographs, Scrapbooks, and Albums.

scopecontent.p: The earliest records within the St. Mary Chapel administrative files series are fragmentary and incomplete. For the years 1921 to 1942, the only surviving documentation are three volumes containing listings of Sunday pulpit announcements. There is greater information for the period since 1942, including correspondence with the archdiocese of Detroit, and correspondence relating to the Gabriel Richard Fundraising Drive. Of interest is correspondence of Father John Fauser between 1967 and 1969, which provides an idea of the changing role of the church and worship format in relation to the social upheavals of the 1960s. The period of 1969 to 1979 is covered in greater detail largely because of the creation of the Chapel Council whose minutes are part of this collection.

did.unittitle: Newspaper accounts and other materials relating to the founding and early history of St. Mary Chapel
Correspondence (mimeographed communications from Archdiocese of Detroit)
Chapel Council (BEDL: Black Economic Development League)

scopecontent.p: The Gabriel Richard Center series consists primarily of correspondence generated as a result of the fundraising campaign for the construction of the student center. Including topical files and correspondence, this group of records is noteworthy in that it illustrates the capacity of the local Catholic hierarchy to raise money. The correspondence includes letters from automobile and other executives who were active in the alumni fundraising effort.

The Newman Club records are more fragmented, and provide little insight into the early history of the Club. The period since the revision of the constitution and by-laws in 1956 are documented in greater detail.

The Miscellaneous series includes topical files, not clearly generated by either the Newman Club or the Student Chapel. This material consists in part of reports and minutes of various other ecumenical campus organizations, and printed materials of various state and national Catholic organizations.
Newsletters include parish, archdiocesan, and campus bulletins published during the period from 1966 to 2000.
The Photographs, Scrapbooks, and Albums series contains photographs and newspaper clippings related to church events, building construction, and significant clergy members.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: Newsletters of the parish dated before 1966 and after 2000 have been separately cataloged and are available in the library's printed collection.
